Sample Outputs: mistral-small-creative

− Iteration 1 — Avg Score: 77.8
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 70.9
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**The Azra Gambit** *Chapter Two: The Offer* --- The transfer vessel hummed with the quiet efficiency of a machine built for precision, not comfort. Arthur Neegan sat stiffly in a high-backed chair of polished durasteel, his fingers tracing the unfamiliar seams of his borrowed suit—a thing of dark synth-silk, tailored to a fit he didn’t recognize as his own. The collar itched. The cuffs were too tight. He had spent the last decade in pressure suits and dust-choked overalls, not in the kind of clothing that whispered of off-world influence and quiet threats. Outside the reinforced viewport, the void stretched endlessly, punctuated only by the occasional flicker of a distant drive flare. They were well beyond Colonial Mars now, accelerating toward some unnamed rendezvous point in the outer system. The Antares diplomatic insignia—three silver stars arranged in a triangular formation, encircled by a laurel of blackened steel—gleamed on the bulkheads, a reminder that this was no ordinary transport. A chime sounded. The door at the far end of the cabin hissed open. Arthur didn’t turn. He had learned, in the last forty-eight hours, that sudden movements were unwise. “Mr. Neegan.” The voice was smooth, cultured, the kind that belonged to a man who had never had to shout over the grind of a drill or the groan of a collapsing mine shaft. “I trust the accommodations are to your liking.” Arthur exhaled through his nose. “They’re fine.” The man who stepped into view was tall, his face sharp-angled beneath a crown of silvering hair, his posture that of someone who had never known the weight of gravity’s pull on a low-g world. He wore a high-collared coat of deep violet, the fabric shifting subtly in the cabin’s dim light—some kind of adaptive weave, Arthur guessed, the kind of thing that adjusted to temperature, to mood, to the unspoken hierarchies of power. “My name is Veyra,” the man said, taking the seat across from Arthur without waiting for an invitation. “I represent interests that have taken a… *particular* interest in your recent discovery.” Arthur’s fingers twitched. “You mean the Azra vein.” Veyra smiled, just slightly. “Precisely.” A silence settled between them, thick with the unspoken. Arthur had spent enough time around corporate reps to know when he was being measured. He met Veyra’s gaze, unblinking. “You’re not with the Antares Corps,” Arthur said. Veyra’s smile didn’t waver. “No. But they *are* with us.” Arthur’s stomach tightened. The Antares Diplomatic Corps was a neutral party—or so the treaties claimed. But neutrality was a luxury, and Azra was anything but. “You’re mining syndicate,” Arthur said. Veyra tilted his head, as if considering the word. “Among other things.” Arthur leaned back, the chair creaking. “Then you know I don’t own the rights to that vein. The lease is held by—” “By *Corporate Exo-Mining*,” Veyra interrupted, “a subsidiary of the Veythari Conglomerate, which, in turn, answers to the Antares Trade Authority.” He steepled his fingers. “A neat little chain of command, isn’t it? All very *legal*.” Arthur’s jaw clenched. “So what do you want from me?” Veyra’s eyes gleamed. “The same thing everyone wants, Mr. Neegan. *Control*.” Arthur barked a laugh. “You think I’ve got control? I’m a foreman. I push paper and keep the drills running. I don’t even *own* the land.” “No,” Veyra agreed. “But you *found* it.” Arthur went still. Veyra leaned forward, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial murmur. “You see, Mr. Neegan, Azra isn’t just a metal. It’s a *key*. A catalyst. The decay rates you’ve observed? They’re not natural. They’re *engineered*.” Arthur’s breath caught. “That’s impossible.” “Is it?” Veyra’s fingers tapped against the armrest, a slow, deliberate rhythm. “Tell me, have you ever wondered why the Antares Corps has taken such an… *active* interest in Colonial Mars? Why they’ve stationed a full diplomatic contingent in a backwater mining colony, when the nearest proper world is three jumps away?” Arthur had wondered. Of course he had. But he had assumed it was just another layer of corporate oversight, another set of hands dipping into the profits. Veyra’s smile turned razor-thin. “They’re not here for the Azra, Mr. Neegan. They’re here for what the Azra *hides*.” A cold prickle ran down Arthur’s spine. “What the hell are you talking about?” Veyra reached into his coat and withdrew a small, flat device—no larger than a data slate, but matte black, its surface unmarked save for a single, pulsing blue light. He set it on the table between them. “This,” he said, “is a fragment of the *original* Azra deposit. The one that wasn’t mined. The one that was *buried*.” Arthur stared at it. “Buried by who?” Veyra’s gaze didn’t waver. “By the same people who built the drives that use it. The same people who *invented* it.” The words hung in the air, heavy with implication. Arthur’s mind raced. The drives. The weapons. The *arms race*. “You’re saying Azra isn’t natural,” Arthur said slowly. Veyra didn’t answer. He didn’t have to. Arthur’s hands curled into fists. “Then what the hell is it?” Veyra’s voice was quiet. “A relic. A tool. And a *warning*.” Arthur’s pulse hammered in his ears. “A warning against what?” Veyra’s smile faded. “Against the people who left it behind.” The cabin seemed to tilt. Arthur’s thoughts spiraled—corporate wars, diplomatic cover-ups, something older than humanity itself, buried beneath the dust of Mars. Veyra reached out and tapped the device. The blue light flickered, then stabilized into a slow, steady pulse. “They want you to sign over your claim,” Veyra said. “Not to Exo-Mining. Not to the Conglomerate. To *them*.” Arthur’s throat was dry. “Who’s *them*?” Veyra’s eyes were dark, unreadable. “The people who don’t want this getting out.” Arthur swallowed. “And what do *you* want?” Veyra leaned back, his expression unreadable. “I want you to *refuse*.” The words hit like a physical blow. Arthur’s breath came sharp. “You’re asking me to piss off the Antares Corps. The Conglomerate. *Everyone*.” Veyra’s smile returned, slow and dangerous. “I’m asking you to *survive*.” Arthur’s fingers dug into the arms of the chair. “Why me?” “Because you’re the only one who’s seen it,” Veyra said. “The only one who *understands* it. And because, Mr. Neegan, you’re the only one who can *stop* it.” Arthur’s mind reeled. He thought of the drills, the veins of blue-green metal glinting in the dark, the way the decay rates had spiked when he’d run the tests—too fast, too *clean*, like something designed. Like something *alive*. Veyra stood, smoothing his coat. “Think carefully, Mr. Neegan. The offer on the table is simple: sign, and you walk away with enough credits to buy your own world. Refuse…” He let the words hang. “And you become the most valuable man in the system.” Arthur’s voice was rough. “And if I refuse?” Veyra’s gaze was steady. “Then you had better hope you’re as clever as I think you are.” The door hissed open behind him. Veyra turned, then paused. “Oh, and Mr. Neegan?” Arthur looked up. Veyra’s smile was gone. “Don’t trust the Corps.” Then he was gone, leaving Arthur alone with the pulsing blue light and the weight of a choice that could unravel the galaxy.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a solid understanding of classic science fiction conventions and successfully captures many elements of Asimov's style. The author establishes an intriguing premise involving ancient alien technology disguised as a natural resource, which is a quintessentially Asimovian concept that blends hard science fiction with mystery elements. The dialogue-heavy structure works well, with Veyra serving as an effective exposition vehicle while maintaining an air of menace and mystery. The conversation feels natural and serves multiple purposes: revealing plot information, establishing character dynamics, and building tension. Arthur's responses are believable for a working-class engineer thrust into galactic intrigue. The world-building effectively captures the retrofuturistic aesthetic requested, with details like "durasteel," "synth-silk," and corporate hierarchies that feel appropriately classic sci-fi. The political complexity involving multiple corporate entities, diplomatic corps, and hidden agendas creates the sense of larger forces at work. However, the piece suffers from some pacing issues and relies heavily on exposition dumps. While Veyra's revelations are intriguing, they come in rapid succession without sufficient breathing room for Arthur (or the reader) to fully process each bombshell. The transition from "Azra is engineered" to "it's alien technology" to "it's a warning" feels rushed. The prose is generally competent but occasionally veers toward overwrought territory with phrases like "razor-thin smile" and "weight of a choice that could unravel the galaxy." Some descriptions feel unnecessarily elaborate, particularly the clothing and technology details that don't significantly advance the narrative. The characterization of Arthur is somewhat thin - while his working-class background is established, his personality doesn't emerge strongly beyond being reactive to Veyra's revelations. Veyra is more compelling as the mysterious antagonist/ally figure, though he borders on being too archetypal. The ending effectively sets up future conflict and maintains the mystery while giving Arthur (and readers) enough information to understand the stakes. The final warning about not trusting the Corps provides a nice hook for continuation. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 17 Believable Character Actions: 15 Nuanced Characters: 12 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 14 Elegant Prose: 13 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Emotionally Complex: 11 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 8 Overwrought: 9 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 15 Overall Impression: 15

+ Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 82.2
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations. The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Darkroom Revelations** The darkroom hums with the quiet whir of the enlarger, the chemical tang of developer thick in the air. Red light bleeds across the counter, turning Elliot’s pale skin the color of old wine. He’s hunched over a tray, his long fingers—nails bitten to the quick—carefully rocking a sheet of photo paper in the stop bath. The sleeves of his oversized black sweater are pushed up, revealing the delicate bones of his wrists, the faintest smudge of ink where he’s been doodling in the margins of his notebook. I lean against the counter beside him, arms crossed, trying to look like I’m not watching the way his throat moves when he swallows. “You’re doing it wrong,” I say, but my voice comes out softer than I mean it to. Elliot glances up, his dark eyes catching the red light like polished obsidian. “Am I?” “You’re supposed to agitate it in a figure-eight. Not just… swirling it like soup.” He exhales through his nose, something between a laugh and a sigh, and adjusts his grip on the tongs. “Right. Figure-eight. Got it.” I should step back. Give him space. But the darkroom is small, and the air between us feels charged, like the second before a storm. I’ve spent the last month stealing glances at him in class—his slouch in the thrifted velvet blazer, the way he bites his lip when he’s concentrating, the quiet confidence in his voice when he talks about photography like it’s sacred. He’s not like the boys I usually go for—all swagger and sharp jawlines, the kind who know exactly how to kiss me against a wall and leave me breathless. Elliot is different. Softer. *More.* And now he’s telling me he’s been questioning his gender. The words had slipped out earlier, when we were setting up the darkroom, his voice so quiet I almost missed it over the hum of the ventilation fan. *“I don’t know if I’m a boy,”* he’d said, like it was something he’d been carrying for a long time. *“I don’t know if I’m anything, really.”* And just like that, the ground beneath me had shifted. I’ve never been with someone like him. Never wanted to be. But here I am, my pulse thrumming in my throat, my usual boldness tangled up in something new—something that feels like *care.* Elliot pulls the photo from the tray, holding it up to the safelight. The image is a close-up of his own hand, fingers splayed against a cracked windowpane, the light filtering through in jagged lines. It’s beautiful. Haunting. “You’re good at this,” I murmur. He shrugs, but I catch the way his cheeks darken, just a little. “You’re better.” I snort. “Flattery won’t get you out of developing the rest of these.” He smirks, just for a second, before his expression sobers. “Dani…” The way he says my name—like it’s something fragile—makes my stomach flip. I turn to face him fully, my hip pressing against the counter. “Yeah?” He hesitates, his fingers tightening around the edge of the tray. “I don’t know how to do this.” “Do what?” “Any of it.” His voice is barely above a whisper. “Talking about it. Figuring it out. *Being* it.” I want to reach for him. To pull him against me and tell him it’s okay, that he doesn’t have to have it all figured out right now. But I don’t. Because this isn’t about me. It’s about *him.* Instead, I say, “You don’t have to have it all figured out. That’s the whole point, isn’t it? You’re *exploring.*” He looks at me then, really looks at me, and something in his gaze makes my breath catch. “What if I don’t like what I find?” The question hangs between us, heavy and raw. I swallow. “Then you keep looking.” A beat of silence. The enlarger clicks as it resets. Elliot exhales, long and slow, like he’s been holding his breath for years. “I like you,” he says suddenly. My heart stutters. “What?” “I like you,” he repeats, quieter this time. “And I don’t know what that means. If I’m supposed to like you. If I’m allowed to.” I stare at him, my mind racing. This isn’t how it’s supposed to go. I’m the one who’s supposed to be in control. The one who makes the first move, who sets the pace. But Elliot isn’t like anyone I’ve ever known, and neither is this. “You’re allowed to like whoever you want,” I say carefully. “That’s not the part that’s complicated.” “Then what is?” I hesitate. “The part where I don’t know what *I* want.” His eyebrows lift. “You don’t?” I shake my head. “I’ve never… I’ve never been with someone like you.” “Like me how?” “Soft,” I say, the word tumbling out before I can stop it. “Quiet. *Uncertain.*” Elliot’s lips quirk, just a little. “And you usually go for the loud, confident types?” “Yeah. The kind who know exactly what they’re doing.” “And you don’t think I do?” I study him—the way his lashes cast shadows on his cheeks, the way his fingers tap restlessly against the counter. “I think you’re figuring it out,” I say. “And I think that’s… really hot.” His breath hitches. “Dani—” I step closer, close enough that I can feel the heat of him, close enough that I can see the way his pupils dilate. “Tell me to stop,” I murmur. He doesn’t. I reach out, my fingers brushing against the inside of his wrist, where his pulse flutters like a trapped bird. His skin is warm, softer than I expected. “You’re allowed to like me,” I say again, softer this time. “And I’m allowed to like you back.” Elliot’s breath shudders out of him. “What if I don’t know how to do this?” “Then we’ll figure it out together.” His eyes search mine, dark and uncertain. “You’d want that?” I don’t answer with words. Instead, I lean in, slow enough that he can pull away if he wants to, and press my mouth to his. He tastes like coffee and something sweet, like the darkroom chemicals and the faintest hint of mint. His lips are softer than I imagined, his breath warm against my skin. For a second, he freezes—then his hands come up, hesitant, to grip the front of my shirt. I deepen the kiss, my fingers tangling in his hair, and he makes a small, needy sound against my mouth. The darkroom feels smaller now, the red light wrapping around us like a secret. When we pull apart, his lips are swollen, his cheeks flushed. “Dani,” he whispers. I smile, just a little. “Yeah?” “I think I like this.” I laugh, low and breathless. “Me too.” The enlarger clicks again, the timer resetting. Outside, the world is still moving—people laughing, cars passing, life going on. But in here, in this small, red-lit space, it’s just us. Just Elliot, with his quiet strength and his uncertain heart, and me, with my usual boldness softened by something new. Something that feels a lot like *want.* And for the first time, I don’t know what comes next. But I think I’m okay with that.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and emotional intelligence in handling a delicate subject matter. The author successfully captures the intimate, confessional atmosphere of the darkroom setting, using the red light as both literal illumination and metaphorical backdrop for vulnerability and discovery. The characterization is particularly well-handled. Dani's voice feels authentic - her usual assertiveness is convincingly complicated by her attraction to Elliot's vulnerability and her own uncertainty about navigating uncharted emotional territory. The internal conflict between her desire to take charge and her recognition that Elliot needs agency is well-developed and psychologically believable. Elliot emerges as a fully realized character despite being seen through Dani's perspective, with his quiet uncertainty and tentative self-exploration feeling genuine rather than performative. The dialogue strikes an effective balance between naturalistic speech patterns and emotional weight. Conversations feel organic, with appropriate hesitations and incomplete thoughts that reflect the characters' emotional states. The progression from technical photography discussion to personal revelation to romantic tension feels earned rather than forced. The prose quality is consistently strong, with evocative sensory details that ground the reader in the darkroom setting. The author effectively uses the photography metaphors and darkroom imagery without overextending them. Descriptions of physical details - Elliot's "fingers like trapped birds," the chemical tang, the red light transforming skin - create atmosphere without becoming overwrought. The emotional complexity is handled with particular skill. The piece explores multiple layers of attraction, identity questioning, and the intersection of gender exploration with romantic desire without reducing any element to simple terms. Dani's confusion about her own identity in relation to her attraction patterns feels authentic and adds depth to what could have been a more straightforward narrative. The pacing builds naturally toward the kiss, which feels like a genuine culmination of the emotional tension rather than an obligatory romantic beat. The ending strikes an appropriate note of uncertainty and possibility without forcing resolution where none would be realistic. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the prose edges toward being slightly overwrought, and a few instances where emotional beats could have been more subtly rendered. However, these are relatively minor issues in an otherwise accomplished piece. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 79.8
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Stolen Moments in Roma** --- ### **Scene 1: The Near-Collision at Trevi** The morning sun glinted off the wet cobblestones of Piazza di Trevi, where the Trevi Fountain roared with its eternal cascade. Tourists clustered like pigeons, tossing coins into the water, their wishes dissolving into the spray. Among them, Ben—tall, lanky, and perpetually hunched over his guidebook—stood frozen in place, squinting at a map as if it held the secrets of the universe. Alessandra didn’t see him. She was a blur of black leather and red scarf, her motorcycle helmet tucked under one arm as she wove through the crowd, her boots clicking sharply against the stone. She had just delivered a package to a frantic American near the Pantheon and was now late—*again*—for her next job. Her phone buzzed in her pocket, but she ignored it, too busy muttering under her breath about *stupidi turisti* who couldn’t move out of the way. Then—*impact*. Not a crash, not quite, but a stumble. Ben’s elbow knocked into her shoulder as he lurched backward, his guidebook flapping like a wounded bird. Alessandra’s helmet clattered to the ground, rolling toward the fountain’s edge. “*Porca miseria!*” she snapped, whirling on him. “Watch where you’re—” Ben’s face was a mask of horror. “Oh God, I’m so sorry! Are you alright? I wasn’t looking—I mean, I *was* looking, but at the map, and then—” Alessandra blinked. He was speaking Italian. Badly. “*Che cosa?*” she demanded, hands on her hips. Ben swallowed. “Uh. *Mi dispiace molto?*” She burst out laughing. “Your accent is *terrible*.” His cheeks flushed. “I know. I took a crash course before coming here. Clearly, it didn’t take.” Alessandra bent to retrieve her helmet, shaking her head. “You’re lucky I didn’t knock you into the fountain. That would’ve been *dramatic*.” Ben rubbed the back of his neck. “I’d deserve it.” She studied him—rumpled button-down, glasses slightly askew, the kind of man who probably ironed his socks. “You’re British.” “Guilty.” “Of course you are.” She sighed, then jerked her chin toward the fountain. “You were about to throw a coin, weren’t you?” Ben hesitated. “Well, yes, but—” “Don’t.” She stepped closer, lowering her voice. “The real magic isn’t in the wishing. It’s in the *stealing*.” His eyebrows shot up. “Stealing?” Alessandra grinned, then reached into the fountain’s basin with a swift, practiced motion. When she pulled her hand back, a glistening euro coin rested in her palm. Ben’s jaw dropped. “You just—” “*Sì.*” She tossed the coin into the air and caught it. “The fountain gives, the fountain takes. It’s only fair.” Ben stared at her, equal parts scandalized and fascinated. “That’s… not how it works.” “It is if you’re me.” She winked, then turned to leave. “Enjoy your sightseeing, *professore*.” “Wait!” Ben blurted, then winced at his own volume. “I mean—could I, uh, buy you a coffee? As an apology?” Alessandra paused, glancing back at him over her shoulder. The morning light caught the gold flecks in her dark eyes. “You want to buy *me* coffee?” “Yes?” She considered him for a long moment, then smirked. “Fine. But only if you promise not to read your guidebook the whole time.” Ben’s face lit up. “Deal.” --- ### **Scene 2: The Gelato Heist** They ended up at a tiny café near the Spanish Steps, where Alessandra ordered an espresso so strong it could’ve stripped paint. Ben, ever the polite Englishman, asked for a “latte, please,” which earned him a withering look from the barista. “*Un caffè macchiato*,” Alessandra corrected, then turned to Ben. “You’re in Rome. Drink like it.” Ben took a sip of his coffee and immediately regretted it. “Bloody hell.” Alessandra cackled. “First rule of Italy: if it doesn’t burn, it’s not worth drinking.” Ben coughed, eyes watering. “Noted.” By the time they left the café, the sky had darkened ominously. Alessandra glanced up, then grabbed Ben’s wrist. “Run.” “What? Why—” “*Piove!*” The downpour hit like a wall. Alessandra yanked Ben under the awning of a gelato shop just as the heavens opened. Water sluiced down the cobblestones, turning the street into a river. Ben gasped, shaking water from his hair. “Christ, that came out of nowhere.” Alessandra was already peering into the gelato case, her reflection wavering in the glass. “Perfect timing.” “For what?” She didn’t answer. Instead, she turned to the shopkeeper—a harried older woman wiping down the counter—and launched into a rapid-fire stream of Italian. Ben caught only a few words: *“…pioggia… freddo… un momento…”* The woman sighed, then nodded, disappearing into the back. Ben frowned. “What did you say to her?” Alessandra grinned. “That we’re soaked and need a minute to dry off. She’s getting us towels.” “Oh. That was… nice of you.” “*Sì.*” Alessandra’s fingers twitched at her side. Then, with a quick glance at the empty counter, she reached out and *plucked* a single gelato spoon from the display. Ben’s eyes widened. “Did you just—” “*Shh.*” She tucked the spoon into her jacket pocket, then turned back to him, all innocence. “What?” “You *stole* that.” “Borrowed,” she corrected. “I’ll bring it back. Probably.” Ben opened his mouth, then closed it. “You’re a menace.” Alessandra laughed, the sound bright against the drumming rain. “And yet, here you are.” The shopkeeper returned with two towels. Alessandra took them, pressing one into Ben’s hands. “Dry off, *professore*. We’ve got a city to conquer.” Ben hesitated, then obeyed, watching as Alessandra wrung out her scarf with a flourish. “Where are we going next?” She smirked. “Somewhere you’ll *definitely* get in trouble.” --- ### **Scene 3: The Catacombs Gambit** Alessandra led him to the Capuchin Crypt, a place Ben had read about but never imagined visiting. The air inside was thick with the scent of old bones and incense, the walls lined with the skeletons of thousands of monks, their grinning skulls arranged in eerie patterns. Ben swallowed. “This is…” “*Bellissimo*,” Alessandra finished, spinning in a slow circle. “The Romans know how to party.” A tour group shuffled past, their guide droning on in hushed tones. Alessandra waited until they were out of earshot, then grabbed Ben’s hand and tugged him toward a roped-off alcove. “What are you—” “*Zitto.*” She ducked under the rope, pulling him with her. Ben’s heart pounded. “We’re not supposed to be back here.” “Exactly.” Alessandra’s eyes gleamed in the dim light. “Live a little, *professore*.” She reached out, brushing her fingers against a skull’s empty eye socket. Ben flinched. “That’s *disrespectful*.” “No, it’s *romantic*.” She turned to him, suddenly close. “Death is just another part of the city. You have to *feel* it to understand Rome.” Ben’s breath hitched. “You’re insane.” Alessandra grinned. “And yet, you’re still here.” A noise echoed down the hall—the tour group, returning. Alessandra’s hand shot out, grabbing Ben’s collar and yanking him into a shadowed niche just as the group rounded the corner. They pressed together, barely breathing, as the guide’s voice faded into the distance. Ben’s pulse roared in his ears. Alessandra’s body was warm against his, her breath tickling his neck. “You’re enjoying this,” he whispered. “*Mmm.*” Her fingers traced the lapel of his jacket. “Aren’t you?” He should’ve been terrified. He should’ve been *outraged*. Instead, he found himself laughing, quiet and breathless. “You’re going to get me arrested.” “Maybe.” She tilted her head, studying him. “But you’d look good in handcuffs.” Ben’s face burned. “That’s—” “*Shh.*” She pressed a finger to his lips. “The fun’s not over yet.” --- ### **Scene 4: The Sunset Betrayal** By evening, they found themselves on the rooftop of a half-abandoned palazzo near the Tiber, the city sprawled beneath them in a sea of terracotta and gold. Alessandra had “borrowed” a bottle of wine from a street vendor (Ben had pretended not to notice) and now sat with her legs dangling over the edge, the sunset painting her skin in hues of amber and rose. Ben leaned against the chimney, watching her. “You’re going to fall.” “Then you’ll have to catch me.” She took a swig from the bottle and passed it to him. He hesitated, then drank. The wine was cheap and bold, like Alessandra herself. “You never told me what you *do* for a living.” She smirked. “I *told* you. I’m a courier.” “And a thief.” “*Borrower.*” She stretched her arms above her head, arching her back. “And a *lot* of other things.” Ben exhaled, rubbing his temples. “You’re exhausting.” “But you’re still here.” He was. And that was the problem. Alessandra turned to him, her expression unreadable. “Why *are* you here, Ben?” He blinked. “What?” “You’re on sabbatical. You could be anywhere. Why Rome?” Ben looked out over the city, the domes and spires glowing in the fading light. “I needed… something different. Something *real*.” Alessandra studied him for a long moment, then reached into her jacket. She pulled out the gelato spoon from earlier and pressed it into his hand. “Here.” Ben frowned. “What’s this for?” “A souvenir.” She stood, brushing dust from her jeans. “I have to go.” “Wait—” Ben scrambled to his feet. “That’s it? You’re just… leaving?” Alessandra grinned, backing toward the door. “Rome’s a big city, *professore*. You’ll find your way.” “But—” Ben’s voice cracked. “What if I don’t *want* to?” She paused, her hand on the doorframe. For a second, something flickered in her eyes—something soft, something *real*. Then it was gone, replaced by her usual mischief. “Then you’ll have to steal another moment.” She winked. “Good luck.” And with that, she was gone, her laughter echoing down the stairs. Ben stood there, the stolen spoon warm in his palm, the city humming beneath him. He had a feeling this wasn’t the last he’d see of Alessandra. And for the first time in his life, he didn’t mind being wrong.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This contemporary romance piece successfully captures the essence of a whirlwind day in Rome between two contrasting characters. The author demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt, incorporating all requested elements: the motorcycle courier Alessandra, the British academic Ben, their meet-cute at Trevi Fountain, and Alessandra's kleptomaniacal tendencies woven throughout their adventure. The characterization is particularly effective. Alessandra emerges as a vivid, three-dimensional character - her mischievous energy, casual thievery, and enigmatic nature feel authentic rather than forced. Ben's transformation from bumbling academic to willing participant in increasingly daring escapades is well-paced and believable. The cultural clash is handled with nuance, avoiding stereotypes while highlighting genuine differences in temperament and worldview. The dialogue crackles with authenticity, particularly Alessandra's mix of Italian and English, and Ben's awkward politeness gradually giving way to genuine engagement. The author skillfully uses dialogue to reveal character rather than simply advance plot, with exchanges that feel natural and purposeful. The prose demonstrates considerable skill in balancing descriptive richness with narrative momentum. Rome itself becomes a character, with evocative details like "cobblestones glinting with morning sun" and "the city sprawled beneath them in a sea of terracotta and gold." The writing maintains an appropriate tone throughout - playful yet sophisticated, romantic without being saccharine. The structure works well, with four distinct scenes that build tension and deepen the connection between characters. Each scene escalates the stakes slightly while revealing new facets of both protagonists. The pacing feels natural, allowing moments to breathe while maintaining forward momentum. However, there are some minor weaknesses. Certain moments border on being slightly overwrought, particularly in the catacombs scene where the romantic tension feels somewhat forced. The ending, while satisfying, relies on familiar romance tropes - the mysterious departure that promises future encounters. Some descriptive passages occasionally tip toward purple prose, though they generally remain on the acceptable side of the line. The emotional complexity is handled well, particularly Alessandra's ambiguous motivations and Ben's internal conflict between propriety and desire for adventure. The author avoids easy answers, leaving both characters' ultimate intentions somewhat mysterious, which serves the story well. + Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 77.8
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**The Last Outpost – Chapter One** The Outpost’s gravity is acting up again. Not enough to send anyone floating into the ceiling, but just enough to make the whisky in my glass slosh like a nervous heart. I wipe the counter with a rag that’s seen better decades, watching the amber liquid settle into stillness. The regulars don’t even blink at it anymore—just another quirk of life on the rim, where the station’s bones creak and the air recyclers hum like a lullaby for the exhausted. Tonight’s crowd is the usual mix: a pair of grizzled miners from the *Iron Maw*, their faces still streaked with dust from the latest haul; a merchant from the *Silver Vein* arguing with a mechanic over a faulty thruster; and old Manx, who’s been nursing the same beer since I opened the taps. The air smells like ozone, sweat, and the faint metallic tang of the asteroid belt outside, seeping in through the vents. Then *he* walks in. Tentacled dreads—dark green, streaked with silver—hang limp around his shoulders, like he’s been running his hands through them one too many times. His skin is a deep indigo, mottled with stress-patches that pulse faintly at his temples. He moves like a man who’s been chased, but not by anything he can outrun. The door hisses shut behind him, and for a second, the whole bar goes quiet. Not because he’s unusual—we get all kinds here—but because he *looks* like trouble. He slides onto a stool at the far end of the bar, right where the flickering neon sign casts half his face in shadow. His fingers tap once, twice, against the counter. Then he exhales, long and slow, like he’s been holding his breath for light-years. “Vega whisky,” he says, voice rough as asteroid grit. “Neat. Better make that a double.” I don’t move right away. Just study him. The way his shoulders are hunched, the way his eyes dart to the door like he’s expecting someone to kick it in. The Outpost isn’t the kind of place that asks questions, but I’ve learned the hard way that some answers come with a price. “You got credits?” I ask, polishing a glass that doesn’t need it. He doesn’t look at me. Just reaches into his coat—worn synth-leather, patched in places—and slaps a chit onto the counter. The kind that doesn’t ping when you scan it. The kind that’s either fake or hot. I pick it up. Run my thumb over the edge. Feel the faint ridge of a serial number filed down. “This good?” he asks, finally meeting my eyes. His are gold-flecked, pupils slit like a cat’s. Unreadable. I toss the chit back. “Depends. You planning on sticking around long enough to earn it?” A muscle twitches in his jaw. “Long enough to drink.” Fair enough. I pour the whisky, the bottle’s neck clinking against the glass. The liquid glows faintly under the bar lights, like it’s got a secret. I slide it toward him. He downs half in one go. Doesn’t even flinch. Just sets the glass back down with a *click* and stares at his reflection in the polished metal behind the bar. “You got a name?” I ask, leaning against the counter. Casual. Like I’m not already running through every exit strategy in my head. “Does it matter?” “Not to me. But the *Iron Maw* crew over there?” I jerk my chin toward the miners. “They’ve been eyeing you since you walked in. And Manx?” I nod at the old-timer, who’s suddenly very interested in his beer. “He’s got a knack for remembering faces. Especially the ones with bounties on ‘em.” The stranger’s fingers tighten around his glass. “I’m not here for trouble.” “Then you’re in the wrong place.” I wipe down the counter again, slower this time. “The Outpost isn’t a hideout. It’s a waystation. People come, people go. But we don’t ask questions, and we don’t get involved.” He exhales through his nose, a sound that’s almost a laugh. “Yeah. I’ve heard that before.” A beat of silence. The station groans around us, metal shifting in the void. Then the door hisses open again. This time, the whole bar *does* go quiet. Three figures step inside, their boots thudding against the grated floor. Two of them are human—big, armored, the kind of muscle you hire when you want to make a point. The third is a Vexian, all chitin and too many eyes, his mandibles clicking like a metronome counting down to violence. The stranger’s back goes rigid. His tentacles twitch, coiling tight against his scalp. The Vexian’s gaze locks onto him. “There you are, *Kael*.” The name hangs in the air like a death sentence. Kael—if that’s even his name—doesn’t turn around. Just takes another slow sip of his whisky. “Didn’t think you’d find me this fast.” The Vexian’s mandibles spread in what might be a smile. “You left a trail. Blood. Credits. Bad decisions.” He steps forward, the humans fanning out behind him. “You took something that wasn’t yours.” Kael’s glass hits the counter. “I took what was *owed*.” The Vexian’s eyes narrow. “Semantics. Hand it over, and we’ll make this quick.” The miners are on their feet now. The merchant’s gone pale. Manx is already slipping toward the back exit, because he’s old, but he’s not *stupid*. I should’ve known. Should’ve seen it in the way Kael moved, the way his hands shook just a little when he set down his glass. Should’ve known he wasn’t just another drifter passing through. But the Outpost has rules. And one of them is that you don’t let trouble spill over into *your* space. I reach under the counter. My fingers brush the grip of the pulse pistol I keep taped there. Not that it’ll do much against armored goons and a Vexian, but it’s better than nothing. Kael stands. Slow. Deliberate. Like he’s already accepted that this is how it ends. “Last chance,” the Vexian says. Kael’s tentacles lift, just slightly. A gesture of surrender. Or maybe a distraction. Then the lights flicker. Not the usual dimming—the kind that happens when the station’s power core coughs. This is different. A deep, shuddering *thrum* runs through the floor, and the gravity cuts out for half a second. Just long enough for the whisky in Kael’s glass to float free, a golden orb suspended in the air. The Vexian hisses. The humans stagger, off-balance. Kael *moves*. Not toward the door. Not toward the goons. He lunges *over* the bar, slamming into me hard enough to knock the wind out of my lungs. His hand clamps over my mouth before I can scream. “Sorry,” he breathes, voice rough in my ear. “But I need your help.” The gravity kicks back in. The whisky glass shatters on the counter. And the Vexian’s voice cuts through the chaos like a blade: “Kill them both.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt requirements, delivering a cozy sci-fi setting with approximately 60% dialogue in first-person present tense. The author establishes The Last Outpost as a lived-in space station bar with effective world-building details like malfunctioning gravity and the metallic tang of the asteroid belt. The conflict emerges naturally through the arrival of the mysterious Kael and his pursuers, creating genuine tension without resolution. The characterization shows promise, particularly in Nettle's voice as a pragmatic bartender with a hidden past. Her observations feel authentic to someone who's learned to read people and situations. Kael is appropriately mysterious without being a cipher, and the Vexian antagonist has a menacing presence. However, the characters could benefit from more distinctive speech patterns and deeper psychological complexity. The prose generally flows well with good pacing and atmospheric details. The author effectively uses sensory descriptions like the whisky sloshing "like a nervous heart" and the station's bones creaking. The dialogue feels natural and serves multiple purposes - advancing plot, revealing character, and building tension. The action sequence at the end is well-choreographed, using the station's malfunctioning gravity as both atmosphere and plot device. The cliffhanger ending appropriately leaves the conflict unresolved while escalating stakes. Some weaknesses include occasional reliance on familiar sci-fi tropes (the mysterious stranger, the bounty hunters) and moments where the prose edges toward purple without quite crossing the line. The piece could benefit from more unique world-building elements and deeper exploration of Nettle's internal conflict about getting involved. The emotional engagement is solid, creating investment in Nettle's predicament and curiosity about the larger mystery. The tone remains consistent throughout, balancing the "cozy" atmosphere with genuine danger. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 14 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 13 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 14.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 13.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 6.0, Purple Prose: 7.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 80.7
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**GONE SOUTH** *Chapter Two: The City That Eats the Lonely* The air in New Orleans smells like fried dough, cigarette smoke, and something sweet and rotten all at once. Like the town itself is a bruise—pretty on the outside, but if you press too hard, it’ll ooze. I’m standing on a cracked sidewalk in the French Quarter, my backpack digging into my shoulders, my phone clutched in my hand like a lifeline. **12% battery.** The screen flickers when I check it, the glow casting sharp shadows under my eyes. I haven’t slept since the night before last. My brain feels like a radio tuned between stations—static, then a burst of panic, then static again. *What the hell am I doing here?* The question loops in my head, but I don’t have an answer. All I know is that I couldn’t stay. Not after Dad called me a *phase*. Not after Mom cried and said, *“We just want you to be happy, but this isn’t you.”* Like they knew me better than I knew myself. Like I was some puzzle they’d solved wrong. A streetcar rumbles past, its bell clanging, and I jump. My pulse is a drumbeat in my throat. I need to find a place to crash. Somewhere cheap. Somewhere no one will ask questions. I turn down a side street, away from the tourist crowds, and immediately regret it. The buildings lean in like they’re listening. Graffiti tags bleed down brick walls. A guy in a stained wife-beater eyes me from a stoop, his gaze lingering too long. I pull my hood up, even though it’s humid enough to melt. *Don’t look like prey. Don’t look like prey.* I duck into a convenience store, the bell above the door jingling. The clerk, a Black woman with silver-streaked braids and a no-bullshit expression, doesn’t even glance up from her magazine. The AC is on full blast, and I shiver. “You lost, *cher*?” she asks, finally looking at me. Her voice is rough, like gravel under tires. I swallow. “Just… looking for a place to stay. Cheap.” She snorts. “Ain’t no cheap in this city that won’t rob you blind.” She jerks her chin toward the back. “Bathroom’s busted. But there’s a hostel down on Rampart. *If* you got ID.” I don’t. Not the right kind, anyway. She must see the panic on my face because she sighs, flipping her magazine shut. “You running from something?” I hesitate. Then, because I’m tired and my brain is fried, I say, “Yeah.” She studies me for a long moment. Then she reaches under the counter and slides a crumpled flyer across the glass. *“Safe Haven Youth Shelter.”* The words are smudged, like it’s been handled a lot. “They don’t ask questions,” she says. “But they got rules. Curfew. No drugs. No fighting.” I nod, folding the flyer into my pocket. “Thanks.” She waves me off. “Don’t thank me. Just don’t end up in the river.” --- The shelter is a squat, peeling building with a flickering neon sign. The door buzzes when I push it open, and the smell of bleach and old coffee hits me. A white woman with a clipboard looks up from behind a desk. “Name?” “Uh. Taylor.” She doesn’t blink. “Last name?” I hesitate. “Just Taylor.” She scribbles something down. “You got ID?” “No.” She exhales through her nose. “You got a parent or guardian who can vouch for you?” *No. Never again.* I shake my head. She studies me, then sighs. “Alright. But you break curfew, you’re out. You bring trouble in here, you’re out. We clear?” I nod. She slides a key across the desk. “Room 3. Bunk on the left. Dinner’s at six. No phones after nine.” I take the key, my fingers trembling. --- The room is small, with two sets of bunk beds and a single window with bars on it. A girl is already there, perched on the top bunk, her legs dangling. She’s got dark hair shaved on one side, a nose ring, and a tattoo of a snake coiled around her wrist. She’s watching me like I’m a problem she’s trying to solve. “You new?” she asks. I nod, dropping my backpack onto the lower bunk. She swings her legs, boots thudding against the metal frame. “You running from the law, or just your folks?” I don’t answer. She smirks. “Fair enough.” She hops down, landing lightly. “Name’s Rook.” “Taylor.” She tilts her head. “You trans?” I freeze. *How the hell—* She laughs. “Relax. You got that look. Like you’re waiting for the world to catch up.” I exhale, some of the tension uncoiling in my chest. “Yeah.” She nods, like that explains everything. “Cool. So. You got a plan, or you just winging it?” “I don’t know.” She grins. “Good. Winging it’s more fun.” --- Dinner is a sad affair—some kind of stew that tastes like salt and regret—but I eat it anyway. Rook slides into the seat across from me, stealing a roll off my tray. “So,” she says, mouth full. “You got money?” I shake my head. “Huh.” She leans back. “You ever hustle before?” “What?” She grins. “Panhandling. Busking. Whatever. This city’s got more scams than tourists.” I stare at her. “You’re suggesting I… what, beg?” She rolls her eyes. “Not *beg*. Perform. You got a voice? Play an instrument? Hell, you could just stand on a corner and look mysterious. People eat that shit up.” I don’t know whether to be offended or impressed. She must see the hesitation on my face because she sighs. “Look, kid. You wanna survive here, you gotta be useful. Or at least *look* like you are.” I glance down at my phone. **8% battery.** Rook follows my gaze. “You got a charger?” “No.” She reaches into her pocket and tosses me a cracked Android. “Here. It’s a piece of shit, but it holds a charge. Just don’t let anyone see you with it. Rules.” I catch it, stunned. “Why?” She shrugs. “Because I like you. And because you look like you’re two seconds from crying, and I don’t do tears.” I swallow hard. “Thanks.” She waves it off. “Don’t mention it. But if you *do* mention it, I’ll deny it.” --- That night, I lie on the bunk, staring at the ceiling. The shelter is quiet, but not peaceful. Somewhere down the hall, someone is crying. A door slams. A voice mutters, *“Fuck this place.”* Rook’s breathing is steady above me. She’s already asleep, or pretending to be. I think about home. About Mom’s face when I told her. About Dad’s silence, heavy as a tombstone. About the way my little brother, Jake, wouldn’t even look at me. *Was it worth it?* I don’t know. But I do know this: I’m not going back. Outside, the city hums—music, laughter, the distant wail of a siren. It’s alive. It’s dangerous. And for the first time in a long time, I feel like I might belong somewhere. Even if that somewhere is a broken-down shelter in a city that doesn’t give a damn. I close my eyes. Tomorrow, I’ll figure it out. Tomorrow, I’ll survive.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt's requirements, successfully capturing Taylor's voice as a transgender teen runaway navigating their first day in New Orleans. The writing maintains a consistent first-person perspective with mixed tenses as requested, and incorporates both internal monologue and dialogue effectively. The characterization is particularly strong. Taylor feels authentic as a frightened, exhausted teenager making impulsive decisions while grappling with rejection from family. Their voice captures the right blend of vulnerability and defensive bravado. Rook emerges as a compelling secondary character - street-smart, guarded, but unexpectedly kind. The dialogue between them feels natural and reveals character efficiently. The prose style works well for YA fiction, with vivid sensory details that ground the reader in New Orleans' atmosphere. The opening metaphor comparing the city to a bruise is effective, and descriptions like "My brain feels like a radio tuned between stations" capture Taylor's mental state authentically. The writing avoids purple prose while maintaining engaging imagery. Emotionally, the piece succeeds in conveying Taylor's complex psychological state - the trauma of family rejection, fear of the unknown, desperate hope, and cautious optimism. The pacing moves naturally through Taylor's day, from disorientation to finding temporary shelter to meeting Rook. However, some elements feel slightly predictable - the helpful store clerk, the street-smart runaway who becomes an ally. The shelter intake process and Rook's immediate acceptance of Taylor's trans identity, while positive, happen quite smoothly for dramatic purposes. The ending strikes an appropriate balance between hope and uncertainty without being unrealistically positive. The technical execution is solid, with natural sentence flow and coherent scene transitions. The piece maintains engagement throughout and creates investment in Taylor's journey. While not groundbreaking, it's competent young adult fiction that handles its subject matter with sensitivity and authenticity. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 77.0
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**"The Great Pumpkin Heist (Or: How We Almost Died for a Squash)"** Midas adjusted the straps of his makeshift backpack—a repurposed duffel bag stitched together from the remains of a pre-Collapse office chair—and sighed. The morning air was thick with the scent of damp earth and the faint, acrid tang of something electrical burning in the distance. Probably another solar panel array shorting out. Again. Chewy the animatronic koala perched on his shoulder, its fur matted with years of grime and its left ear held together by a strip of duct tape. The koala’s glassy black eyes flickered a cautious yellow—*apprehensive, but game*. “Right,” Midas said, squinting at the hand-drawn map scrawled on the back of a cereal box. “The old greenhouse district. Should be clear of raiders this time of day. Most of ’em are still sleeping off last night’s fermented dandelion wine.” Chewy’s eyes pulsed a skeptical orange. *You say that like it’s a good thing.* “It *is* a good thing. Means we won’t get shot at. Probably.” The koala’s eyes dimmed to a resigned blue. *Famous last words.* --- The greenhouse district had once been a gleaming testament to post-Collapse ingenuity—a network of repurposed shipping containers and salvaged glass, where the last remnants of civilization grew their sad little tomatoes and bitter greens. Now, it was a skeletal husk, picked clean by scavengers and time. The only thing left of value was the rumor: a single, perfectly preserved pumpkin, hidden in the ruins of the old hydroponics lab. Midas had heard the story from a half-mad hermit who traded information for rusted spoons. *“Big as a wagon wheel,”* the hermit had wheezed. *“Sweet as sin. Worth its weight in bullets.”* Chewy’s eyes had flashed a bright, greedy gold at the mention of bullets. *We could trade it. Get real medicine. Maybe even a new ear.* Midas had agreed. Now, as they picked their way through the broken glass and rusted metal, he was having second thoughts. “You’re sure this is the right place?” he muttered, kicking aside a rotting garden gnome. Chewy’s eyes flickered green—*annoyed*. *You’re the one with the map.* “It’s *vibes*, Chewy. I’m going by vibes.” A vibe, it turned out, was not a reliable navigational tool. --- They found the pumpkin. It was, indeed, big as a wagon wheel. It was also *alive*. Not in the way pumpkins are usually alive—plump, orange, and waiting to be carved into a jack-o’-lantern. No, this pumpkin had *eyes*. Beady, black, unblinking eyes that tracked Midas and Chewy as they crept closer. Chewy’s fur stood on end. His eyes burned a panicked red. *That is not a pumpkin.* “It’s *definitely* a pumpkin,” Midas whispered. “Pumpkins don’t have *eyes*.” The pumpkin *blinked*. Midas and Chewy bolted. --- What followed was less a strategic retreat and more a chaotic sprint through a minefield of collapsed greenhouse frames and suspiciously placed tripwires. (The tripwires, they later learned, were not booby-trapped. They were just tripwires. The universe had a sense of humor.) Chewy, being a koala with no legs, was carried most of the way, clinging to Midas’ neck like a furry, panicked scarf. His eyes cycled through every color of the emotional spectrum—*terror, betrayal, existential dread*—before settling on a dull, defeated gray. *We are going to die over a vegetable.* “It’s not *just* a vegetable!” Midas panted, dodging a low-hanging beam. “It’s a *sentient* vegetable! That’s *rare*!” The pumpkin, it turned out, was also *fast*. --- They lost it in the old subway tunnels, where the air smelled like mildew and regret. Midas collapsed against a rusted turnstile, gasping. Chewy slid off his shoulder and flopped onto the ground, his eyes flickering weakly. *I hate my life.* “Could’ve been worse,” Midas wheezed. Chewy’s eyes flashed a single, scathing crimson. *How?* “Well, we’re not *dead*.” Chewy considered this. Then, with a dramatic sigh, his eyes dimmed to a sullen purple. *Yet.* --- They limped back to their makeshift home—a repurposed delivery van parked in the skeletal remains of a shopping mall—just as the sun began to set. The van’s solar panels had been stripped months ago, but Midas had rigged up a wind turbine from an old ceiling fan and a bicycle wheel. It sputtered weakly as they approached, as if even the van itself was disappointed in them. Inside, the air smelled of stale beans and despair. Midas flopped onto his cot, groaning. Chewy dragged himself onto the dashboard, where a single, flickering LED light cast long shadows. *We failed.* “Yeah,” Midas admitted. “But we *tried*.” Chewy’s eyes flickered a reluctant gold. *That’s something, I guess.* Outside, the wind howled through the broken mall windows. Somewhere in the distance, a pumpkin *screamed*. Midas pulled a blanket over his head. “Tomorrow,” he muttered, “we’re raiding a library. Books can’t chase you.” Chewy’s eyes dimmed to a thoughtful blue. *Unless they’re haunted.* Midas groaned. *Worth a shot,* Chewy added. And with that, the two of them settled in to wait for the next disaster. Because in a world where pumpkins had eyes and koalas had opinions, disaster was always just around the corner.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a solid understanding of the Terry Pratchett style, capturing his dry wit, absurdist humor, and matter-of-fact treatment of bizarre situations. The author successfully creates a post-apocalyptic world where an animatronic koala with color-changing eyes serves as both companion and conscience to the hapless protagonist Midas. The story structure follows the prompt requirements well, beginning with deliberation over the day's mission, showing how it goes sideways, and returning the characters home worse for wear. The central conceit of a sentient pumpkin is appropriately absurd and fits the Pratchett-esque tone. The characterization works effectively within the constraints of the format. Midas emerges as genuinely hapless yet persistent, while Chewy's personality comes through clearly via his color-coded emotional responses. Their dynamic feels authentic to their circumstances and personalities. The prose maintains consistent voice throughout, with good pacing and natural dialogue. The author shows restraint in not over-explaining the world-building, allowing details to emerge organically. Descriptive passages like "the morning air was thick with the scent of damp earth and the faint, acrid tang of something electrical burning" effectively establish atmosphere without becoming purple. However, the piece has some limitations. While competently executed, it doesn't reach the heights of genuine Pratchett's philosophical depth or his ability to find profound meaning in absurdity. The humor, while consistent, relies somewhat heavily on the central gimmick rather than developing more sophisticated comedic layers. The ending, while appropriate, feels slightly rushed and could have benefited from more development of the characters' relationship dynamic. The story succeeds as an entertaining pastiche that fulfills its brief without transcending into truly memorable territory. It's well-crafted genre fiction that demonstrates technical competence and understanding of its influences. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 14 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Emotionally Complex: 12 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 15 Overall Impression: 15
